item.title: Multifunction inverses
item.dc:creator: David Kraemer
item.description: When we deal with normal functions we are frequently interested in the behavior of on subsets of , rather than just elements. We might write to denote the image of on the subset . Conversely, given a subset , we can examine the “preimage” of by :

item.title: My summer excursion into multifunctions
item.dc:creator: David Kraemer
item.description: Besides managing a course, my first summer goal is to understand the Berge maximum theorem (BMT). According to Wikipedia, the theorem is useful for describing continuity conditions for the solution of parameterized optimization problems. Since I’m still new to the whole subject, I don’t quite understand what that means! More on its interpretation and applications (hopefully!) soon.

item.title: Reflections on the first year of graduate school
item.dc:creator: David Kraemer

item.title: Semantics for algorithmic accountability
item.dc:creator: David Kraemer
item.description: As someone who uses and, from time to time, designs algorithms for varied purposes, I am bemused when I read about them in the popular press. A New York Times opinion piece (author credit: Ellora Israni) is typical. In it, Ms. Israni argues that the use of algorithms to aid in criminal sentencing is dangerously susceptible to abuse:

item.title: A neat proof of the Cauchy criterion
item.dc:creator: David Kraemer
item.description: I took introductory analysis with Understanding Analysis by Stephen Abbott, and I think it is great for the purpose of a first course in real analysis. However, now that I’ve done a bit more in analysis, I’ve started to revisit some of the important proofs of the textbook with simpler (albeit more developed) alternatives.

item.title: When abstraction is simpler
item.dc:creator: David Kraemer
item.description: I am always delighted when abstraction makes a problem noticeably easier to solve. Today I encountered (Jacod 1999) the following homework question:
